block.p: KOSOVO: BANNED PAPER IS BACK -- An Albanian-language newspaper temporarily banned by Kosovo's chief United Nations administrator reappeared carrying the same article that led to the ban -- an account the United Nations says contributed to the killing of a Serbian employee. Two weeks after The Dita accused a Serbian translator for the United Nations in April of membership in a Serbian paramilitary unit that expelled Albanians last year, the man was found stabbed to death.

SPAIN: RUSSIAN SEEKS INVESTMENT -- President Vladimir Putin arrived in Spain for a two-day visit where he is meeting with officials and business people to urge Spanish investment in his country. At a banquet, King Juan Carlos offered Spain's help in consolidating political and economic reforms in Russia and called on Moscow to ensure freedom and justice for its citizens.

BRAZIL: MAYOR RESTORED TO OFFICE -- A Brazilian court ordered Celso Pitta, the fallen mayor of Sao Paulo, back into office less than three weeks after ousting him amid a flurry of corruption accusations. The ruling by the Supreme Justice Tribunal in Brasilia can be appealed to Brazil's Supreme Court.

BOLIVIA: CALL FOR NEW UNIVERSITY -- Tens of thousands of students and parents marched through the capital, La Paz, demanding that the government create a new independent university. Traffic was paralyzed in the center of the city through much of the day in another in a series of demonstrations that has disrupted La Paz over the last several months.

ARGENTINA: UNEMPLOYMENT RISES -- Vice President Carlos Alvarez suggested that the current 14 percent unemployment rate could rise to 14.5 percent in official government statistics to be released in a few weeks. That would mean that two million Argentine workers are without jobs. Last October, just before President Fernando De la Rua took power, the unemployment rate stood at 13.8 percent.

ARGENTINA: APOLOGY FOR NAZI AID -- At a news conference in Washington, President Fernando de la Rua apologized for his country's role in harboring Nazi war criminals and vowed to get to the bottom of two anti-Jewish bomb attacks in the last decade. After World War II, Argentina received thousands of Germans, including Adolf Eichmann, who directed the killing of millions of European Jews.

IRAN: JEWS' TRIAL NEARS END -- Four of 13 Iranian Jews accused of spying for Israel returned to court for a brief hearing as the trial approached its close, and a defense lawyer hammered away at what the state calls confessions of guilt by eight of the accused. ''They may have made confessions in the past but one must not forget they were in prison for a long period and confessions made during such a long period are not always exact,'' said the lawyer, Esmail Nasseri. Officials predicted a verdict by next week.

SIERRA LEONE: CLASHES NEAR CAPITAL -- Rebels attacked United Nations positions and clashed with government troops northeast of the capital, Freetown, as hundreds of British troops began leaving the city. British troops sent in last month to secure Freetown after rebel forces took hundreds of peacekeepers hostage are due to depart tonight, leaving behind just 200 soldiers to train 1,000 recruits for the new Sierra Leone army.

NIGERIA: FUEL STRIKE OVER -- Labor leaders called off a crippling five-day general strike after President Olusegun Obasanjo apologized for sharply raising gasoline prices without consulting Nigerians. Under an agreement with labor leaders, the government agreed to gas prices slightly below those set on June 1. Increasing Nigeria's heavily subsidized gas prices is considered a financially necessary, but politically explosive, measure.

ZIMBABWE: ELECTION MONITORS WARNED -- President Robert Mugabe told international observers coming to scrutinize the June 24-25 election that they would have free access to white-owned farms occupied by pro-Mugabe war veterans since February. However, the veterans' leader said the observers could speak with his men but not with farm workers, saying that would be ''unacceptable'' interference.

PAKISTAN: ANTI-TAX ACTION SUSPENDED -- Markets throughout the country were back to normal, reopening after a strike by store owners against the military government's crackdown on tax evasion. But the shutdown has been suspended for only 15 days, leaders of the businessmen warned. If their demands go unmet, the strike will resume, they said.

PAKISTAN: ACCUSATION OVER KASHMIR -- Reading a statement at his corruption trial, the ousted Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif said for the first time that the military had kept him in the dark until May 1999 about its ''Kargil'' operations in the mountains of Kashmir. Had he known of the plans, he said, he would never have allowed Prime Minister Atal Behari Vajpayee of India to visit Pakistan on a peace mission three months earlier.

SRI LANKA: LOAN FROM INDIA -- Desperate for cash in its fight against the Tamil Tiger rebels, the government has been promised $100 million in loans from India. A joint announcement was made in Colombo as Jaswant Singh, India's minister of external affairs, ended a visit to the war-ravaged nation.
